title: Iron deficiency in pregnant mice causes XY embryos to develop with female characteristics
summary:
Nature, Published online: 04 June 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01456-7

In mice, a lack of maternal iron impairs an iron-dependent enzyme that activates the male sex-determining gene, causing some XY embryos to develop ovaries.

title: Simulation of matter–antimatter creation on quantum platforms
summary:
Nature, Published online: 04 June 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01581-3

Two-dimensional quantum platforms have simulated a process in particle physics called string breaking that generates matter–antimatter pairs.

title: Sticky membranes of dead red blood cells obstruct small vessels
summary:
Nature, Published online: 04 June 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01457-6

Damage to the vascular lining leads to interactions with red blood cells that hint at how to treat dangerous complications of heart attack, stroke and COVID-19.

title: How I’m bringing the voices of local fishers into ocean policies
summary:
Nature, Published online: 04 June 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01667-y

Fishing communities know what sustainability means. They must be at the decision table.

title: Why we should protect the high seas from all extraction, forever
summary:
Nature, Published online: 04 June 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01665-0

Exploitation of the high seas risks doing irreversible damage to biodiversity, climate stability and ocean equity. A consensus must be built now to save them.

title: Y-chromosome loss in cancer and immune cells might worsen treatment outcomes
summary:
Nature, Published online: 04 June 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01450-z

Prognosis is poor for tumours with Y-chromosome loss. Examining the interplay between cancer and immune cells sheds light on potential mechanisms.

title: Cancer more deadly when tumours lack Y chromosomes — and the loss could be contagious
summary:
Nature, Published online: 04 June 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01656-1

Losing the Y chromosome seems to make cancer cells more aggressive in men and the phenomenon might even spread between cells.

title: How a mysterious epidemic of kidney disease is killing thousands of young men
summary:
Nature, Published online: 04 June 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01689-6

Repeated damage from extreme heat over time seems to be a leading factor causing kidneys to fail.

title: Making robust integrated photonic qubits
summary:
Nature, Published online: 04 June 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01696-7

High-performance photonic integrated chips have been demonstrated that generate robust optical quantum bits called Gottesman–Kitaev–Preskill qubits. One such chip has been used to realize qubit states, reconstruct the quantum features of these states and verify the quality of the qubits.

title: Should there be a national holiday in honour of chemists?
summary:
Nature, Published online: 03 June 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01560-8

A proposal to bring science to the public’s attention, and Arctic explorers set sail in style in this week’s pick from the Nature archive.

title: Local predictions of climate change are hazy. But cities need answers fast
summary: Scientists are figuring out where “downscaled” climate models struggle—and how they can be improved

title: Some Dead Sea Scrolls are older than researchers thought, AI analysis suggests
summary: But overall, machine learning approach closely matches what human scholars had long suspected about ancient documents
